content.webTitle: CD: Art Pepper, Work of Art

fields.headline: Jazz review: Art Pepper, Work of Art
fields.bodyText: There were two big jazz comebacks from long drugs absences in the 1970s: Chet Baker's, and the saxophonist Art Pepper's. Like many musicians of the predominantly white "cool school" of the 1950s, Pepper favoured long, twisting, unemphatic melody lines over big climaxes or raucous blues-bashing. But he wasn't the stereotypical cool-jazzer. His emotional edginess lead him to far more unpredictable, almost Monkish alternations of urgency and silence; his tone pulsated with passion and doubt. This four-CD collection traces his work between 1952 and 1957, from Charlie Parker-inflected music through the 1956 Hollywood sessions that included Baker and the incomparable tenor-sax master Warne Marsh (one of Pepper's most compatible partners), up to a legendary session in Miles Davis's rhythm section - the eight tracks from which are worth the box.
